alternative_title: Ask for a lenient Crown Court sentence to be reviewed
body:
$!If you think someone's Crown Court sentence is too low, you can ask for it to be reviewed.$!

The Crown Court only deals with cases in England and Wales. Only certain types of case can be reviewed, including:

- murder
- rape
- robbery
- child sex crimes and child cruelty
- some serious fraud
- some serious drug crimes
- crimes committed because of the victim's race or religion

^Anyone can ask for a sentence to be reviewed - they don't have to be involved in the case.^

Only one person needs to ask for a sentence to be reviewed. 

##How to complain

You should contact the Attorney General's Office as soon as possible after the sentence is passed. The time limit for making a complaint is 28 days after sentencing. 

You should provide as much information as you can about the case, eg the:

- name of the person who got the sentence
- date the sentence was given
- court where the case was held
- crime committed

$C
**Attorney General's Office**  
[www.attorneygeneral.gov.uk](http://www.attorneygeneral.gov.uk/ "Contact the Attorney General's Office"){:rel="external"}  
<correspondenceunit@attorneygeneral.gsi.gov.uk>  
**Telephone:** 020 7271 2492    
Monday to Friday 9am to 5pm    
$C

The Attorney General has 28 days to review a sentence and make a decision. Once the case has been reviewed, it may be sent to the Court of Appeal.

##The Court of Appeal

The Court of Appeal may decide that the sentence:

- should stay the same
- is unreasonably low (called 'unduly lenient') and may increase it

^Even if a case is passed on to the Court of Appeal it may not change the sentence.^
overview: How to complain to the Attorney General's Office if you think someone's sentence is too low - and what happens if the Court of Appeal get involved
title: Complain about a low Crown Court sentence
